comments.commentBody:
The 'fiscal cliff' negotiations are clearly being structured to cut spending on Medicare and Medicaid (and possibly Social Security), while retaining upper bracket tax cuts in the name of stimulus. My hope is that citizens will deluge the White House, the Senate and the House with letters, e-mails and tweets conveying their thinking on tax policy and social insurance spending.

While I believe that a case that can be made that the Bush tax increases could be extended until the economy is substantially recovered, I also oppose Social Security cuts, as well as reductions in Medicare and Medicaid benefits, especially for middle- and lower-income Americans. I do favor allowing the government to negotiate price cuts with hospitals, insurers, nursing homes and drug providers selling goods and services under the Medicare and Medicaid plans, as well as raising or eliminating the Social Security income cap.

If tax policy is changed, it should raise taxes and/ or limit deductions on upper bracket households-- I'd suggest that upper bracket be defined at $500,000 in income. As well, I would impose super-bracket levies on incomes worth $1 million or more, and estates worth $5 million or more.

*One last item: those interested in retaining Social Security and Medicare should stop using the term "entitlements". "Entitlements" is pejorative. These programs are "paid in" insurance programs.*

I have Samsung ARM Chromebook. I also have deployed some at my job. They are very useful for cloud-based services. I use Google Apps, Smartsheet, Expensify, Lucidchart, and other SaaS programs.

At work, the maintenance team takes a Chromebook to another division and keys in job data to Smartsheet. The type of data is recurring tasks completed or preventative tasks by priority. The job data is all instantly available and has a complete history of past entry. Chromebook is very useful for activity like this as it is lightweight and has a full keyboard, the parts are all solid state, and it is fanless with no heat.

As Pogue says above, the simplicity of the OS is a feature. While the Chromebook cannot run java or Soon-To-Be-Obsolete Program 2013, it also does not run those things as a feature. While the Chromebook will delete your old files when it runs out of space making it inadequate to archive files on the local disk and forcing users to use Google Drive or some other cloud storage service for archiving, it also never runs out of disk space and integrates cloud storage as a feature. In the time it takes to cold boot this machine, do some computing tasks, and turn the machine completely off, most devices are still booting.

"Now's the time to contact our reps in DC."

Is anybody organizing a campaign to get the masses of voters to do just that? Move On? Anyone?

President Obama did a great service to our country when he made the focus of his campaign informing the public that we have been engaged in fierce class warfare with the middle class and the poor always ending up the loser, for over thirty years. Finally, he got people to listen and they got out and voted. For that, I thank him as well as the OWS crowd who showed him Americans were ready for a conversation about income inequality.

To Professor Krugman's point about deception, it is truly amazing just how scurrilous are the efforts of the big money guys to camouflage their intent to continue to control our wealth and resources in the name of deficit reduction. Lloyd Blankfein (net worth - $450 million;
annual salary - $55 million) wants "serious cuts in discretionary spending and entitlements." He's a member of "Fix the Debt" which cloaks its agenda to underfund Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security as the best way to reduce the debt. Then, they'll cough up some extra tax revenues, but only then. Classic bait and switch.

These people will never give up. Now's the time to contact our reps in DC, both Democrats and Republicans and put them on notice that we voted for fairness and we expect them to deliver.

i believe the French already having something similar in place where someone who does hard labor gets benefits earlier than an accountant, for example, because working later in life is more possible in one versus the other.

What would be progressive (if unlikely to be adopted) is a rule that ties retirement age inversely to income I suspect. So if one is working a lousy minimum wage job, one gets *full* social security at 62. If on the other hand one is a banker or even a tenured professor one only gets full social security at say 72.

There are more people here than there were in 1995. Are you saying we should cut population back to that level? You want to institute a one-child policy like China did? Good luck with that.
Just because we might not be able to balance the budget soley on raising income taxes on the rich, does not mean we should not do it at all. The rich have had huge tax cuts for years, and they were already supposed to have expired, so now we should let them expire. Cutting defense spending and corporate welfare would also help. Raising the estate tax would help.
No, it might not be possible to balance the budget by raising income taxes on the wealthy alone, but that should be done first!
You're correct, it won't fix the deficit on its own. But it's a really good start.

It is a mathematical impossibility to even come close to balancing the budget by raising income taxes on the wealthy alone.

The author of this story has to understand this so I do not understand why he never talks about the cuts that will have to happen somewhere or the tax increases that will inevitably have to hit everyone to maintain current spending levels.

What we need to do is revert to 1995 spending levels adjusted for inflation. I remember 1995 and we did not have people dying in the streets from lack of government assistance so I think we would be fine going back to those leveles of spending.

And yes, I support cutting defense spending and corporate welfare.

I hope Rick Perry isn't doing the praying, or the GOP is going to be in even more trouble.

No wait, I hope he is.
Yes, but as others here have pointed out, where are the pure Conservatives to go? They're certainly not going to vote for Democrats.

Ron Paul did not do that well, did he?

The GOP prefers their delusions and mythic thinking to realism and knowledge. That means they CANNOT attract the intelligence, perspicacity and judgment politicians now need to succeed. Not to mention some concern for the actual everyday lives of people. They've been accustomed for far too long to believing they could shape and mold the public at will. That hegemony seems to be ebbing away.

Sigh. Jack is making some weird round-about argument. I am not talking proxies like college graduates per state. I am talking actual polls of actual voters. Polls showed that those with ADVANCED degrees went 55% for Obama. So the super-educated backed O. Look no further than this very website:

http://elections.nytimes.com/2012/results/president/exit-polls

This is why our current system of electing a president doesn't bother me totally. You get a real sense of how a candidate's team approaches problem-solving. "This can't be that hard" suffers a disadvantage versus "I know how this works".

Of course, it does bother me that our elections are as close as they are, given this empirical evidence demonstrated during the long campaign.
In that table, shouldn't those numbers be percentage points, not percent? In San Francisco, didn't Obama actually beat Romney by more than 500% -- 84% to 13% -- but 71 percentage points?

There are a lot of moderate Republicans who are put off by the way the far right (yes, the Religious Right) has co-opted the party. There are even (GASP!!) GAY Republicans. I respect an intelligent and reasoned argument. I do NOT respect dogma -- and I don't much care what the dogma is. As far as scientific truth is concerned, extremists can't dismiss it just because they don't believe in it. It reminds me of the old teaser, "How many legs does a dog have if you call its tail a leg?" Answer? FOUR!! You can call its tail anything you want, but it's still a tail.

You have bravely stated the case for a moderate look at the issues facing the country. If there were more Republicans like you, we might at last be able to find a COMPROMISE (which means nobody gets everything they want but everybody gets something) and once again the political system would work.

Cal E . . . "high-income tech industry professionals" are not voting againts their one economic interests, they are voting FOR those interests. This country works best when we the people agree to pay for the things we, collectively, have told our elected representatives that we want provided for us.

The GOP thinks it is OK to be given things without paying for them, but progressives think, rightly I'd have to say, that such behavior is irresponsible.

In search of unbiased information you might try reading the Republican platform.
I think JD is objecting to the article "the" in "the Silicon Valley."
Sorry, dear.  White angry older males are not 'this nation.  They are simply another minority.

Drive from San Antonio to Dallas on I-35 in tax-averse Texas.  This stretch is notorious for deadly accidents.  The concrete is cheap, shoulders are sometimes non-existant, on-ramps are sometimes 150 feet long with no alternative to "merge or ditch" (die).  An 18-wheeler coming on has no choice but to bull his/her way on.  More roads and cars are not the answer, but my point is that in blue states you will find an appreciation for community funded quality-of-life improvements that, for example, allow for safer transportation.   Looking ahead, a broader public-transit will be completed in Seattle in the next 10 years.  The key words are "community, public, and safety", in contrast to "self -interest, individual, and private".  The former requires consensus...the latter, well, ultimately guns I guess.  All those states that "keep their tax money" don't seem so much wealthier than my community...er...I'm talkin' to you, deep South red states...

This is like arguing that the GOP built a better bridge but it failed. Simply on the mechanics of being a candidate, Romney with all the advantages he had at his hands was a disaster.

And all the 'creativity' in the world will not make contrafactual positions legitimate -- denialism in all its various forms, budgets that don't add up, 'science' that isn't so.

Not to mention the general mean spiritedness and lack of empathy of both the Republican platform and most of its adherents.
Actually, over one third of our army and marines are African American or Hispanic, who voted with their ethnic bloc.

Good point. Raising the top marginal tax rate will increase taxes on the incomes of people who earn income by actually working rather than those who earn income by investing. However, if that part of the Bush tax program that reduced capital gains tax from 20% to 15% does not survive, that will raise substantial taxes on wealthier 'capitalist' individuals who get most of their income from investments.
I admit it is troubling that no one seems to talk about the rise in the capital gains tax. I hope that it is included in any fiscal cliff deal. If not, we will be increasing taxes on brain surgeons and owners of small businesses and leaving the super-rich alone.

starting 1/1/13 the capital gains rate is slated to go from 15 to 20%

maybe more imporantly qualified dividends is going from 15% to
whatever bracket you are in....

then if you make over 250k as a married couple; tack on another 3.8% medicare surcharge...and don't forget the estate...

the exemption goes down to 1 million.

***that dividends increase can have some huge repercussions from the super wealthy****

I just don't see how raising the marginal rate is going to fairly raise revenues.  Raising marginal rates has no effect on income which has preferential tax treatment. It would seem to me that restoring preferentially treated income to the calculation of AMT would be a much fairer way of raising revenue.
